subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. I've been
gone for a few days from the daily
monologues. I've managed to do, I think,
125 without
interruption. But now there's been an
interruption and there's an interesting
story behind it. Because you see, I'm not
quite the same person I was a few days
ago. I've become a little bit more of a
cyborg
since then. Yes, a cyborg. You are looking
at a cyborg. What I mean, specifically,
is right here, it's still healing up: I
have a pacemaker. I have a computerized
device that has been implanted inside
of my body that is sending electrical
signals into my heart to control my
heartbeat. It's really something. We live
in a world in which people are becoming
more and more like cyborgs and I've
taken a big step in that direction.
You know, years ago when it became a fad
for young people everywhere to pierce
their bodies, their tongues, their
noses, their ears, their lips, body
piercing has become a big thing globally.
I had the intuition that this is
just a step in the direction of: people
will be becoming part human and
part - I don't want to say exactly
mechanical, I'm looking for the right
word - cyborgical, perhaps. We are
combining our bodies with the
instruments of technology. So, we are very
slowly and gradually mutating ourselves,
[like me and] my pacemaker. You know, when I
was born they did not exist. This is a
development in
my lifetime. Although, I studied the
history of it, and actually, you could
say there are intimations of this going
back thousands of years when they used
to stimulate people with electrical
fish if their hearts had stopped. Well,
there's a lesson in all of this and
here's where it begins. About 10 years
ago I was on a treadmill test, stress
test in a cardiac facility in Las Vegas
where I then lived, and my heart actually
stopped for about 6 seconds while I
was on the treadmill. I nearly lost
consciousness, but I didn't. But, you can
imagine, it freaked out the people
working there administering the
treadmill test. Here is this guy about to
lose consciousness on the treadmill.
They sent me to see a heart rhythm
specialist 10 years ago. This man, a
very good doctor to the best of my
knowledge, said, "We got to immediately
give you a pacemaker."
I said, "Why?" He said, "Look, your heart
stopped for 6 seconds. What more do you
need?" I knew better, at least I
thought I did. I consulted with a
cardiologist I knew, Pim van Lommel, who is
an expert in near-death experiences [and] lives
in The Netherlands.
We were communicating via email. I
explained to him in great depth why I
didn't believe I really needed a
pacemaker despite of the obvious
indication there. I explained: I'd
been having, they're called syncopes,
loss of consciousness. I've had them
since I got married, some 40 years ago. In
the early days I did lose consciousness,
but subsequently I had learned to detect
the onset of this syncope experience
because it has what's called an aura. You
can tell that it's coming, it's about to
start. When I feel
that it's about to start I've learned that I can
make a fist with both of my hands and
retain consciousness. I also learned
that for me, this experience which is
known as vasovagal syncope, occurs
typically if I'm engaged in athletic
activity, like I'm running, sprinting and
then I stop suddenly. Or, occasionally if
I'm in the hot tub and I get up suddenly. It
has to do with low blood pressure. I
learned that I could prevent loss of
consciousness. In fact, I didn't lose
consciousness when I was on the
treadmill. These experiences were very
rare in my life and I decided that,
you know, if I was in danger I could
control it. I explained all this
to Pim van Lommel and he said, "Well, I think
you're right. You probably don't need a
pacemaker now. But you will eventually."
Ten years ago I was in my early 60s and
I figured by the time I'm 70 or so, I am
going to need a pacemaker. I knew that,
but it was in the back of my mind. I
wasn't paying a lot of attention to it
at all. So, I have this pacemaker now. It
was put in on Friday, the 6th of
July, two days ago and it happened
suddenly. You see, now I'm in a new
community. I went to see a cardiologist
here in Albuquerque, just to check in.
He said, "Well, I see you have a bit of an
irregular heart rhythm. Why don't you see
the heart rhythm specialist, just check
in with the fellow." I did. I had a nice
talk with this doctor, brand new. I was
his first Albuquerque patient, although
he was a very experienced doctor who had
moved here from Farmington, New Mexico.
He spent a lot of time with me and
he said, "Well, lets hook you up to
a 30 day heart event monitor and
then we can make a better determination
of what you need."
He called me up suddenly on Thursday,
the 5th of July. He said, "Look, your heart
monitor just showed that your heart
stopped for 3.5 seconds."
Well, no big deal to me. I didn't feel any
symptoms. But he said 3.5
seconds between heartbeats, that's less
than 20 beats a minute.
He said, "You're at risk. I need to give
you a pacemaker." I thought, well,
there's no rush. But then I realized I
have a busy travel schedule and if I'm
going to meet my travel commitments and
also allow time to recover from the
surgery I better get this pacemaker put
in right away. So, the very next morning
there I am in the hospital. It was an
outpatient procedure, but it lasted all
day. I was there from 8 am to 5 pm.
I think the procedure itself ran
about 4 hours, because in addition to
putting in a pacemaker, they actually did
what's called an ablation, which is, he
manages to put an electrical wire with
I guess a laser attached to it all the
way into my heart, going up from a vein
in my groin.
I'm wired up with all kinds of
monitoring going on. I'm half conscious.
They sedated me but did not anesthetize
me, so they could actually talk to me
during the procedure. But the sedation…
this is so interesting from the
point of view of consciousness. I'm half
awake and able to speak to the doctors, but
after the procedure is over, I have no
memory of it whatsoever. They do so much
with these various drugs that can affect
consciousness and I think it's quite
interesting. This is all about
consciousness really, about losing
consciousness and regaining
consciousness. Because of the fact
that I've experienced these vasovagal
syncopes for decades it's been something
I've been well aware of. In fact,
typically, when I start to get one of
these
syncopes, it is very seductive. I get this
feeling I'm going into a deep, sweet
space, it's like, this feels good. I might
have an out of body experience and I'm
kind of looking forward to it, getting
ready to enjoy it. But my wife who sees
me losing consciousness freaks out a
little, but I don't blame her. So,
she's encouraged me not to go with it,
but rather to fight it, so of
course I have, for her sake. I don't want
to frighten her. Well, here I am now with
a pacemaker. The irregular heartbeat,
or AFIB that I had has been removed
completely. My heart is beating faster,
it's beating more regularly. I expect
this is going to extend my lifespan. My
mother-in-law had a pacemaker and she
lived to be 98, in fact. She used to
complain, she said, "I don't want to live
so long. If I didn't have this pacemaker
I could die, which would be good." She
didn't want to live to be 98. I think she
outlived her husband by 30 years. But
that's what pacemakers will do. They will
extend your life. So, I'm glad to have it.
That means I'll be with you longer, if all
goes well. But, what is the lesson for you
in this? Let me ask you this. Think
back about 10 years ago in your life. Did
you ever have an indication, an inkling, a
sense, maybe a very direct warning that
10 years from now you have 10 years and
you better take care of a particular
issue, but you've been putting it off,
you've been ignoring it, it seems like 10
years is a long time, and then all of a
sudden 10 years sneaks up on you. There's
something that you need to take care of
that you've been neglecting maybe for
the past 10 years? Something equivalent
maybe to the pace-
maker that I now have, in your life? What
might that be
for you, if anything? I'll leave you
with that thought. Thank you for being
with me, once again. I look forward to
being with you in these monologue
experiences many more times.
